body: ON a Saturday night in May 2003, Holly McKnight of Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, was too tired to ride into Manhattan for a night at a club. So she reluctantly agreed to meet friends at a nearby disco. ''It's filled with wannabe gangster types like in 'The Sopranos,' '' said Ms. McKnight, now 29. ''Everybody thinks they're 'connected.' The men have a
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Holly McKnight and Anthony Lauretta

body: An article in some copies on Sept. 24 about several stabbings and shootings in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn misidentified the Brooklyn neighborhood where the nightclub Club Reflections, the scene of one stabbing, is located. It is Flatbush, not Kensington.
title: Corrections

body: Across the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn early yesterday, in a public housing complex, a subway car and a packed nightclub, a handful of unrelated stabbings and shootings claimed the lives of two men and injured two more, according to the police. About 1 a.m., outside the Edenwald Houses, a public housing project at 1150 East 229th Street in the
title: In City, 2 Die and 2 Are Hurt In Attacks in a Span of Hours

body: YOU can smell the horses before you can see them, although if you're walking off the overpass that straddles the busy Prospect Expressway in East Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, the pungent odor of hay and manure seems out of place among the warehouses, semidetached row houses and passing cars. Kensington Stables, at Caton Place and East Eighth Street,
title: THE VOICE; When the Horsemen Passed By

body: A New York police officer has been charged with sexually abusing his half-sister, 23, twice last year, the authorities said yesterday. The officer, Hector Vargas, 36, of 365 Walker Street, was charged with two counts of forcible touching and two counts of third-degree sexual abuse, both misdemeanors, said a spokesman for the Staten Island district
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Police Officer Charged With Sex Abuse

body: To the Editor: We read with interest ''Finding a Family House (Cue The Bagpiper)'' (The Hunt, March 5) and felt the need to share our part of the story. In September 2005 we, too, were looking to trade up from a two-bedroom apartment on Ocean Parkway (a couple of blocks from the former co-op of Celine and Garry Cheddy). We also attended the open
title: Searching for a Dream Home

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: TO Celine Cheddy, a house meant space and freedom. To her husband, Garry Cheddy, it meant responsibility and repairs. ''I wanted a house for a very long time,'' Mrs. Cheddy said. ''House hunting has been an ongoing process, ongoing for a number of years. We fought a lot about buying it.'' In the meantime, she said, ''I gave up and bought a co-op.''
title: THE HUNT; Finding a Family House (Cue the Bagpiper)

body: NEW YORK -- sung about by Frank Sinatra, chronicled by Carrie Bradshaw and trampled by King Kong -- has long had mythic status. Even the real estate is legendary. Rents have always seemed exorbitant compared with those in other big cities, and now buying in Manhattan costs a record-setting $1,002 a square foot, on average. Still, there are plenty
title: A World of Affordable Choices

body: The snowstorm started slow and wet, and as the night and the next day wore on, it did a lot of things -- it paused, it got stronger, it got weaker, it got stronger again. But one thing it didn't do, for 24 hours, was stop. It made its point in fits and starts, trading brief lulls for blinding whiteouts in minutes. It arrived late Saturday, and by
title: A RECORD SNOWFALL: THE SCENE; Sunday Turns White, Windy And Hushed

body: EASON--Charles Francis, Sr. On January 21, 2006 at age 93 in Bethesda, MD. Born April 7, 1912 in Brooklyn, NY to Charles Aloysius Eason and Katherine Marie Larkin. He was predeceased in 2005 by Eleanor Butler Eason, his wife of 54 years. He leaves 4 sons, Charles Francis Eason, Jr. of Washington, DC, David Butler Eason of Chevy Chase, MD, Paul
title: Paid Notice: Deaths EASON, CHARLES FRANCIS, SR.

body: MAHBOOB AWAN, a dignified, matchstick-thin Pakistani immigrant, had $20,000 and an escape plan. Weary of the hustle and squalor of his 26 years as a New Yorker, fed up with the cramped, roach-infested apartment that he shares with his wife and two little boys in Kensington, Brooklyn, he wanted out. ''New York has nothing for me,'' said Mr. Awan, a
title: The Great Escape
